title: How to Use Agile & Scrum in AI Product Management
subtitle: Adapting traditional methodologies for the unique challenges of AI product development
excerpt:
Why Agile is a Good Fit for AI Projects

AI projects involve uncertainty, evolving requirements, and experimental research. Agile helps by offering:

  • Iterative development: Frequent model updates and experiments.
  • Stakeholder feedback: Aligns AI outputs with business needs.
  • Early delivery: Deliver MVPs to collect data or validate ideas.
  • Risk management: De-risk complex model development in small increments.

Scrum Roles Adapted for AI Teams

Scrum roles reimagined for AI product teams:

Scrum RoleAI Team Equivalent
Product OwnerDefines backlog, prioritizes experiments, bridges business and data science.
Scrum MasterFacilitates agile rituals, removes blockers, fosters collaboration.
Development TeamComprises data scientists, ML engineers, backend/frontend devs, and analysts.

Scrum in AI Product Development

Scrum in AI should adapt for model experimentation and data exploration:

  1. Sprint Planning: Identify backlog items like preprocessing, model training, etc.
  2. Daily Stand-ups: Discuss blockers like low data quality or training issues.
  3. Sprint Reviews: Demo metrics, model insights, or feature outputs.
  4. Retrospectives: Improve based on data drift, model failure, or deployment delays.

Managing AI Backlogs

AI backlogs should include research, uncertainty handling, and model tasks:

  • Include spikes for research or unknowns.
  • Define clear acceptance criteria like accuracy thresholds.
  • Use experimentation tickets for model comparisons.

Sample Sprint Backlog

TaskTypeOwnerStatus
Collect user clickstream dataDataData EngineerIn Progress
Train classification modelMLML EngineerTo Do
Hyperparameter tuningExperimentML EngineerTo Do
Build prediction UIFrontendWeb DevDone

Challenges & Solutions

ChallengeSolution
Unclear model KPIsDefine business-aligned metrics like precision, recall.
Variable data qualityInclude data validation and audits in sprints.
Slow training timesPlan experiments around compute schedules.
Cross-functional gapsEncourage communication via daily standups and shared docs.

Best Practices

  • Align vision: Connect sprint tasks to AI goals.
  • Involve stakeholders: Validate outputs regularly.
  • Track experiments: Use MLflow or Weights & Biases.
  • Focus on explainability: Integrate SHAP, LIME early on.

Conclusion

Agile and Scrum provide adaptable, iterative frameworks to build, test, and scale AI products. By tailoring ceremonies and roles, teams can better manage complexity, improve collaboration, and deliver smarter outcomes.
